courses.name: PHYS 101 - “Introductory Physics - Mechanics”]**

assessments.title: Weekly problem sets done online via the Ans system.  Multiple attempts allowed; full marks for correct answer regardless of attempts.
assessments.description: Weekly problem sets done online via the Ans system.  Multiple attempts allowed; full marks for correct answer regardless of attempts.

assessments.title: Weekly assignments throughout the semester
assessments.description: Weekly assignments throughout the semester - 15% (lowest dropped)

assessments.title: Weekly problem sets, done online via the Ans system.
assessments.description: Weekly problem sets, done online via the Ans system.

textbooks: *Physics, Principles with Applications* by Douglas Giancoli, 7th edition, from Prentice Hall (used copies available at McGill bookstore)
otherInfo: Course uses a flipped classroom approach.  Pre-lecture readings and discussions are required (Perusall platform; 7% of grade in default scheme).
Weekly tutorials (10% of grade in default scheme; 2 lowest dropped) in small groups led by undergraduate peer mentors; multiple time slots available.
Labs (20% of grade; required to pass the course; 55% minimum). One virtual and six in-person sessions.
Four grading schemes are available; students must choose by September 15th.  Default scheme recommended.
Students should plan to spend 10 hours per week on the course.
A scientific calculator is required.

Late or missing assessments will receive a 0 unless prior arrangement is made with the instructor for significant and documented reasons.  Lowest two Perusall and tutorial scores, and lowest assignment score are dropped.
Regrades must be requested within 10 days of grade release.  Contact specific email addresses for different assessment types.
Course covers mechanics and waves; detailed schedule provided in the syllabus.
Use of generative AI is discouraged for assignments but permitted for understanding course materials.
Students can submit written work in English or French.

courses.name: Introductory Physics - Mechanics

assessments.title: Weekly problem sets done online via the Ans system.  Allows multiple attempts; full marks if correct regardless of number of tries.
assessments.description: Weekly problem sets done online via the Ans system.  Allows multiple attempts; full marks if correct regardless of number of tries.

assessments.title: December, [date]: Final Exam
assessments.description: December, [date]: Final Exam - 30% (Default), 35% (Option A), 35% (Option B), 40% (Option C)

textbooks: College Physics, 2e by OpenStax - [ISBN not specified]
Physics, Principles with Applications, 7th edition by Douglas Giancoli - [ISBN not specified]
Used copies available at the McGill bookstore.
otherInfo: Course uses a flipped classroom approach.
Pre-lecture reading and discussion activities (Perusall) are worth 7% (default). Lowest two scores dropped.
Tutorial participation is worth 10% (default). Lowest two scores dropped. Tutorials are held in small groups; attendance and participation required.
Labs are worth 20% and are required to pass the course (minimum 55%).  One virtual lab and six in-person sessions. Reports due at the end of each lab.
Four grading schemes are available; students must choose by September 15th.

Lectures are held Tuesdays and Thursdays, 1:05-2:25 PM in Leacock 132, from August 29th to December 3rd, excluding the week of October 14th (Reading Week). Lecture recordings may be available on MyCourses.
A scientific calculator is required.
Students should plan to spend 10 hours per week on the course.
Late or missing assessments receive a 0 unless prior arrangements are made with the instructor for significant and documented reasons.
Regrades must be requested within 10 days of grade release.  Different email addresses for different inquiries.
Use of generative AI is allowed for understanding course materials but not for producing assignments.
Students can submit written work in English or French.

courses.name: Linear Algebra and Geometry
courses.instructor: Dr. Jeremy Macdonald (coordinator), Dr. Romain Branchereau, Miguel Ayala, Antoine Giard

assessments.title: Assignments released every Friday, due Sunday of the following week.  Multiple attempts allowed; each problem has equal weight.
assessments.description: Assignments released every Friday, due Sunday of the following week.  Multiple attempts allowed; each problem has equal weight.

textbooks: Linear Algebra with Applications by W. K. Nicholson - Not specified
otherInfo: Grading Scheme:  Final grade is the higher of two schemes: Scheme 1 (Webwork 15%, Midterm 20%, Final 65%) and Scheme 2 (Webwork 15%, Final 85%). Letter grades are assigned based on a provided scale (with potential lowering of boundaries at instructors’ discretion).
Email Policy: Use email only for individual matters; use the Ed discussion forum (linked in myCourses) for other questions.
Course Website: myCourses
Tutorials: Weekly tutorials led by teaching assistants; strongly encouraged to ask questions.
Homework Policy: Collaboration allowed, but problems cannot be solved by others (humans or AI).
Resources for Math Help: Office hours, tutorials, Ed discussion forum, Burnside Math Helpdesk, SciLearn Peer Collab.
Life Difficulties: Contact instructors if life difficulties interfere with studies.
University Policies: Policy on Assessment of Student Learning (PASL), Academic Integrity, Language (English or French), Accommodations (handled by Student Accessibility and Achievement).
Disclaimer: Course content and evaluation scheme subject to change due to extraordinary circumstances.
